subject: Re: How do I change the timezone used for the timestamp in the XML formatter?
msgSnippet: Thanks for the pointers.  I found the file I need to modify in the ant-junit.jar file (That was the file actually being used), but I can t seem to make the
messageBody:
Thanks for the pointers. I found the file I need to modify in the
ant-junit.jar file (That was the file actually being used), but I
can't seem to make the adjust-dateTime-to-timezone command work.

I changed:
<xsl:value-of select="$insamepackage/@hostname"/>

to:
<xsl:value-of
select="fn:adjust-dateTime-to-timezone($insamepackage/@timezone,
America/Denver)"/>

results in the following error:
[junitreport] : Error! The first argument to the non-static Java
function 'adjustDateTimeToTimezone' is not a valid object reference.

I think I'm on the right track, but I'm not an XSLT expert. I'll wait
for our resident XSLT expert to come in tomorrow, and let you all know
what I find.

Thanks for all your help,

Steve
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains762@...> wrote:
>
> j_cumps wrote:
>
> > Steve,
> >
> > Search for timestamp in the Ant stylesheets (located in Ant's etc
> > folder). That is the place where the date/time is wtrittrn to your
> > html doc.
> >
> > Try to convert it to your timezone using the function fn:adjust-
> > dateTime-to-timezone(datetime,timezone), documented on
> > http://www.w3schools.com/xpath/xpath_functions.asp
> > <http://www.w3schools.com/xpath/xpath_functions.asp>
> >
> > Regards, Jan
>
> Thanks, Jan; I knew someone here knew how to do this with XSL
> transformation.
> --
> J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger :: http://www.jbrains.ca
> Your guide to software craftsmanship
> JUnit Recipes: Practical Methods for Programmer Testing
> 2005 Gordon Pask Award for contribution Agile Software Practice
